description:
I was running errands and happened to walk by this coffee house on my walk home. I was drawn in from the milk bubble tea sign on the windows and decided to go in. The smell inside was a mixture of body odor and I don't know, spoiled food? It was confusing and I didn't like it, but I kept walking to the back counter anyway because I had to give this tea a try (and a chance). The man handling the orders and register wasn't exactly friendly but he wasn't mean either. He just didn't seem like he wanted to take my order. After placing, I probably waited 4 minutes until my bubble tea was ready. What a pleasure! It was great. The black tea had great, strong flavor and it was warm at first because he had just brewed the tea and it needed to be shaken a bit before it all became the same temperature. The boba was nice and chewy, not exactly fresh boba or homemade tasting, but still good and there were lots of it.

I ended up getting the size large soy milk boba tea and it cost me $6 with a small tip. Comparatively to other boba places in the city, I thought it was a good size for the price. It was $4.50 for the large and an additional 0.40 cents for the soy milk plus tax. I don't know that I'll come back for anything other than the boba because I wouldn't want to eat inside the restaurant, but maybe I'd consider getting something to go.

4 rating for the tea but a 2.5/3 for the restaurant because of the smell.
author: Bri T.

description:
You won't believe it, but I worked here back around 1976-77. And it's still here! The layout is basically the same. Order at the window. Sit down and wait for your order to be prepared by the individuals in the kitchen. Whether it's a bagel and cream cheese, a slice of carrot cake or an espresso coffee drink, the set up, process and results are the same as they were back then. 
Take your time. Relax. This unique coffee establishment will entertain and relax you. 
The bulletin board is still there. The step from the main area to the order window is still there. 
I enjoyed my visit down memory lane.
author: Eric K.

description: Can't go wrong with their breakfast foods, best homemade hash browns I've ever had. Their staff is super friendly too (I think they're a couple)! Even their bagels taste great compared to other places I'm not sure why or how. The inside is also a nice place to lay back and read a book or take a seat and enjoy your morning coffee.
author: Paul I.

description:
I work nearby and heavily rely on this cafe for my morning and afternoon pick-me-ups. If you've never been here before, make sure to watch your step when walking towards the counter! You order where the huge menu is. The owners are friendly and efficient--the mister always greets me, takes my order, and works his magic, sending me on my way in 10 minutes or less. Most often less. 
I highly recommend trying the "fogs" here if you haven't - my favorite is the London Fog, which is an earl grey tea latte. I can't say much about the food since I only tried their lox here and it was pretty good for the portion and price. My colleagues often purchase food here though and enjoy the sandwiches. 
Regular coffee comes in two options: French roast or dark roast. *They have a credit card usage for $5 minimum. If you're like me and don't normally have cash on you, add a cookie from the cookie jar ($1.95) and you'll be safe to use your card. 
Plenty of seating and some nice comfy sofas too. Afternoons tend to be busier with more people studying/socializing. Free WiFi and they have poetry nights.
author: Debby N.

description: I love this place! I work nearby and ordered eggs and avocado and a coffee to go on my break. I didn't tell her I was pressed for time but she made my eggs really quick and handed them to me right away. I was so impressed at her consideration and kindness.
author: Melissa R.

description:
Sacred Grounds Coffee House has a lots of wood in it's infrastructure to give it a rustic feeling.
front and back floors are uneven, watch ur step up when going to order.  sammies pricing about same as Cindy's, meat more descriptive.(roasted,  mesquite,,)

 pastries/cakes/pies slices also available.

brew: organic forest french roast blend (2)
-smooth, slightly bold, not silky

drips:
-seating all in the front section
-not a lot of space, lots of sunlight...
author: Victor G.

description: I got the chai tea latte and they poured it from the box in front of me. It was horrible ..
author: Sam M.

description: Cozy neighborhood coffee shop. Breakfast is served all day! Nice selections for lunch, breakfast, or a quick bite.
author: Pamela H.

description: Dear lord. I wanted to like this place because it looks so cute and cozy. But I leaned against the counter when I was signing the credit card slip and realized it was COVERED in tiny little ants or termites. If the front counter is like this I don't want to know what the kitchen is like. Won't be back for a long time.
author: Angel V.

description:
Good food. I got a lox everything bagel with cream cheese, tomato, onions and capers and my friend got the breakfast sandwich on a croissant with sausage, egg and melted cheese.

Lots of seating, free wifi, friendly staff and freshly squeezed oj. Good place to come work and have some food.
author: Jeffrey G.

description: I LOVE it here. I live two blocks away and you can find me in here 3-4 times a week studying or just stopping to get coffee.  They are friendly with great prices, coffee, and breakfast sandwiches.  My favorite thing about Sacred Grounds is it is not one of the thousand "trendy" coffee shops that are all are SF. It is very genuine and welcoming in here and they actually have comfortable seats which i think is rare.  Anyways highly recommend.
author: Cassidy D.

description:
Rude and unfriendly staff. 

First time there so I was obviously unsure of what to order. Asked which cold drink they could suggest, instead of being welcoming, the guy seemed upset that I had even asked him. Didn't even give me an answer, just told me to look at their cold drinks menu.. I ended up buying an iced latte and a bagel. 

Not worth it, would not come back.
author: Denise S.

description:
The owners are extremely kind and friendly. I really appreciate that!

The cafe is really spacious and has a relaxing and low-key vibe to it. 

I normally get sandwiches when I am there. They are tasty and reasonably priced. I've also tried the London Fog tea, which is super delicious. I can't comment on the quality of the coffee though as I have never tried it.
author: Claire L.

description:
Cute place recommended by a coworker who goes at least once a week. Why 5 stars? No complaints! 

Set-up: feels like a neighborhood coffee shop (warm and worn-in), order counter tucked in the back around the corner. Not a big place, but the seating area is spaced out well. 

Food: I very much enjoyed my BLT with avocado on wheat! The special, a chicken club with cheese and avocado, was also a great meal when I had it later. Sandwiches come with chips and a drink, I believe. 

Service: The owner isn't effusive but is relatively friendly, overall pleasant, and efficient. I don't need small talk, just give me a sandwich and a yummy strawberry-banana smoothie and I'm good! I came on an off time (~1:45pm) but I got my order (two sandwiches and a smoothie) within 5-10 minutes. Not pre-made--I saw the owners make them! Wish I could multi-task that well! 

I think the sandwiches are just a liiiittle bit pricey, but they taste good and it's convenient, so what the hell. In fact, I'm going there after I finish this review!
author: Jasmine G.

description:
Quasi ground floor/basement space that feels warm and cozy instead of dark and cramped.

Maybe it's the quiet but nice owners and the clientele that ranges from parents with small babies to students and true hippies (that anchored this neighborhood when it was shabby and a lil dangerous) that give The Sacred Grounds a nicely worn feel like a favorite old shoe.

And they make a really good Americano.
author: Jennifer O.

description: Family owned, unpretentious, low-key, old-school coffee house. Lots of plants and bulletin boards with community flyers. They have BOBA TEA! Classic coffee drinks, wifi, couches. Great spot if you're sick of all the hip new fancy places and want a cozy, real coffee shop.
author: Ashley M.

description:
This place is very chill, and is like a comfy room in a friends house, with books to read, and other bric-a-brac to give it that homey feel. 

There is a street level section in the front, then a step down area in the back where you order from the counter. The tables are rustic and wood. 

I came on a Saturday morning to meet someone and it was very relaxing. Not crowded at all, a nice leasurely slow pace to it, like a throw back to the hippie days of SF. 

I had a Soy Latte, and I also had Lox and Bagels ($7.50). Reasonable prices. 

It is a block or two from the PanHandle area. I will be back.
author: Wanugee N.

description:
This place is right across the street from New Traditions Elementary School. This is important for those who don't already know. I would guess that the majority of the clientele around both pick up and drop off times for the school are parents of students. In the afternoon they will have their children as well. 

The coffee and drinks are average, the place is cozy and they have food. You can grab s sandwich and a bottle of beer.
author: Ben M.

description:
Came here while i was waiting for my brother was at the hospital which is close by to this coffee place.

Order the thai ice tea since it was a bit warm in sf. Cost 2.75. Decent price for a medium size cup. Its an alright drink. Its a bit bland/semi sweet. It gives you a somewhat a mild bitter after taste after each sip

This place is a small coffee shop place. they don't have a lot of option but its still can be a place where you can eat lunch, breakfast, get coffee, cold drinks, snacks, etc and hang out with your friends. And its also its a good place if you want to study or browse the internet while drinking your coffee

Theres enough tables and chairs. Also they have sofa too and small book section you can check and plants out which it makes it homey. 

They have wifi but you'll have to ask for their password if you want to use their wifi.
author: Julie N.

description: So-so coffee but friendly staff/owners and tons of open seating. Free wifi. Nice quite neighborhood. I wouldn't go out of my way to come back but if I'm in the area I'd swing by!
author: Joey B.

description:
I was visiting a relative at St.Mary's Hospital, and needed a bite to eat for lunch. I walked down the block, and saw this sweet place, and decided to go check it out. 
Walking in, you would swear you were in a bar. The layout is similar to a lot of pubs in SF. There was great decor, and I admired the potted plants in the window.
The food was also quite good. I ordered a coffee and a BLT. The bacon in the BLT was quite plentiful, however the portion of chips it comes with did not suit the meal, as they were tortilla chips. The coffee was hot, and fresh out of the pot, and really hit the spot.
The staff were kind, and if I was ever in the area again, I would probably stop for just a coffee this time.
author: Seamus G.

description: Amazing this place is still around and still as it was during San Francisco's best years. Today: coffee great as was my grilled chicken salad. Yea!
author: David K.

description: They want to work you for hot water.  It's the cozy choice though.  No wifi and stink eye was returned when they refunded half of the hot water money.
author: Kevin C.

description:
I asked if he could melt some cheese over chips. His response. NO. How bout "no, I'm sorry."
#rude not another dime.
author: Margot G.

description: Stopped by after my doctor's visit and I love this place because they have London Fog!!!! Very friendly family owned café:)
author: Maitai N.

description:
Great breakfast sandwiches. Decent coffee. The owners are really friendly and provide great service.

If its only one person working the counter it can take a long time to order and get served. I've had to leave and get coffee elsewhere just because of this.
author: Ross H.

description:
Coffee is good, simple.  Place is cozy.  But it's the fact there is like an army of ukulele players having a lesson/jam session that has gone on for at least an hour that just earned an extra star.  

Wifi password is coffeehouse.
author: Drew T.

description: A Mom and Pop place, and by mom and pop I literally mean it's run by a cute older Asian couple. They have a five dollar minimum to use cards, so if you're just planning on having a drink bring cash. Prices are very resonance I got a salad with all the bells and whistles (avocado) for about seven dollars. They have a nice ambiance and homey decor so it almost feels like you're studying at home. I recommend the iced green tea although I wish they brewed it ahead of time and had it refrigerated because they brew it on the spot and it gets diluted with the cold ice cubes that melt. Their bathroom has some interesting writing and they don't paint over it so there's lots of years of good reading in there.
author: Vanessa B.

description:
I love this little cafe. The owner, Teddy is always very nice and accommodating--he really appreciates his customers. It's your standard little Costco-to-storefront cafe, but it suits me just fine for being steps away from my boyfriend's apartment. I always get an everything bagel with bacon, avocado, tomato and cream cheese--it makes for the perfect little breakfast sammich and it's noticeably cheaper than bread & butter cafe breakfast bagels down the way. The London Fog is my favorite for hot beverages and their iced coffee and chai is pretty great too. 

They do get a little frazzled when it's busy, but that's okay--it's a small shop and I understand--plus I'm never in a hurry in the mornings :] support this local business!
author: Caitlin G.

description:
The only cafe with food near St Marys Hosp.  This place could have more potential if they only put the effort. 

Just like what the other reviewer wrote, health hazard!!!  They touch/make food after handling cash or credit cards whether they r using gloves or bare hands, no washing! DIRTY!!! 

Ordered their combo with hot soup & sandwich.  I thought it'd be a full sandwich, but NO!!! They cut the bread in half & gives me the smallest sandwich I've ever eaten!!! What am I, a child? Did I order a kids meal for $9?!?!?  After making my meal, they hand me a coffee cup with my soup in there...seriously!?!  With the $9 you stole from me, this place cant afford a soup bowl from Costco where they buy their muffins & "fresh" tub of nestle cookies!!!  What a waste of & sorry of cafe this place is!  Who ever gave this cafe more than 3 stars must be on drugs or maybe need to be on it.  

Don't bother going here is all I have to say!!!
author: Wanderlust F.

description: Have you ever had coffee? Me too. It's really wonderful here. I like iced coffee. Do you like breakfast sandwiches? Me too. They serve amazing breakfast sandwiches at Sacred Grounds. Here's what you do: get the croissant, with ham, and American cheese alongside your iced coffee before checking out the Golden Gate bridge. I think you will enjoy it. Also check out poetry night.
author: Daniel M.

description: Reasonable prices, cozy atmosphere, outdoor seating, polite staff.
author: Sean M.

description:
Did not expect much because of the rating, but this place is awesome!! 

Only negative is that John Mayer was on the radio. I have my headphones.
author: david p.

description:
Previously I gave Sacred Grounds 3-stars for having decent but overpriced bagels and coffee, ultimately forgiving them for having TERRIBLE soup. See previous review for more on that. 

After recently having tried their also TERRIBLE sandwiches I must return to detract another star and forewarn my fellow yelpers. Don't order the sandwich! It costs $9.95 and comes with chips and a drink, and on the surface it appears enticing. Don't be fooled. What I saw them make and try to pass off as a $10 sandwich was just wrong! I watched in horror as:

First they took FROZEN cutlets of chicken, then they put it them in the same toaster they use for the bagels to heat it up. Next they microwaved the Oscar Mayer bacon. And then they toasted a hot dog bun. That's right it's served on a hot dog bun. Topping off this gross concoction was browned avocado, green tomato, yellow lettuce, onions, pickles, and your usual condiments. It was about a gas station level sandwich for $9.95.

The bottom line: it's ok for coffee and bagels if you're nearby and need it fast, avoid all products they themselves produce: soups, sandwiches, salads, etc. Would no longer recommend.
author: Tomas K.

description: This cafe has weird vibes.  The cafe is like I am entering a 1970's Grandpa bachelor pad.  Owners are not friendly at all. I live nearby and they are selectively nice to people, however they are consistently unpleasant to me for some reason.  They try to nickel and dime you on everything.  $1 for soy milk added to an Americano  $1.75 for a cup of ice.  Only good thing was the fast internet since I was the only one in the cafe and the slightly above mediocre coffee.
author: Theresa C.

description: Awesome place that offers great customer service. No, it's not your typical SF minimalist coffee shop charging too much for artisan products. It's comfy, warm, simple, and inviting. The prices are awesome and the snacks are delicious. Free wifi too.
author: Will M.

description:
Nothin worse when someone prepares your breakfast and he doesn't wash his hands or  put on food prep gloves.

To me that's the height of being inconsiderate.
And to top it off.... I think he was the owner.
Asian guy.
author: Terrence J.

description:
Walked in here to get a small bite while waiting for my husband to pick me up. It's Saturday afternoon and here are the things I like so far about this place:

-- there are old people here, chatting, reading newspaper, doing some kind of strange group activity. Clearly this is not hipster nerd only shack. Score.

-- at the same time there's another young lad with his MacBook sitting at the corner. Another point.

--- the guy at the counter is not a hot barista. Yes please.

--- they have real food. I just ordered a piece of toast with an egg ("anyway you want it" he said) and I randomly threw in a slice of cheese on top. Hurray for letting me order random food.

I couldn't give the last star yet because that's my regular star. I would have to come more often to grant that star unfortunately this place is out of my regular active zone yet I really want to review this place before the memory fades.
author: Elizabeth T.

description: As others have reviewed a very chill cafe to hang out at with good food and decent coffee. Although they might not sell the best cup of joe in town, the owners of this mom-and-pop joint are friendly and care about their customers. Hands down one of my favorite places to grab a bite to eat whether I'm working from home or just hungry on a Saturday afternoon.
author: Cameron J.

description:
Service is really poor. Guy behind the counter wed afternoon was a real jerk. He never smiled and was actually pretty rude.

Sandwich was OK- came with reallt dry tortilla chips.. would have been much better with salsa or some kind of dip.

Great coffee!

Free wifi for customers. Nice big tables to work at.
author: Jena D.

description:
I actually have never had the coffee here.  I'm only at USF on Saturdays for class and this has been the usual spot to go to for lunch.  The sandwiches are pretty decent and the prices are cheaper than the stuff they have on campus. I always order the chicken breast on a french roll. It comes with all the fixings including fresh avocados.

It's a small shop and you bus your own tables. The lady at the counter has been really nice every time I've gone.
author: Totran M.

description:
Some tough critics out there....This review speaks only to my "Amazon Fog" tea which consisted of Earl Grey tea, milk, and honey.  It was very hot, and I enjoyed it.  Can't speak to the coffee.

This a.m. it was just one person behind the counter who took the order and prepared the food.  You need to walk past the tables into the back.  Watch the two steps.  The person ahead of me ordered a toasted bagel, so I thought I needed to wait until her order was complete before he took mine.  But he overlapped and I got my completed beverage order in due time.
author: Shirley N.

description:
It is a quaint place...very bohemian with a lot of character. The open mic nights and readings make it especially cool.

The food is basic but decent and the owners (mom and pop) are nice enough.

The coffee is HORRIBLE...most of the time not even very hot. The hours posted here are not what they post in their window and they sometimes close early at their whim.
author: Jack L.

description:
This seems like a quaint place to come and study. There is plenty of seating indoors and comfortable at that. There is a big variety on the menu and I got the SF fog or some name to that effect.

What could be better.

There are supplies and food products strewn about. A case of soda here, a box of napkins on the floor there. Messy and almost cluttered the walkway.
After sitting for a few minutes indoors, I decided it was a nice day outside and worked my way to the table in front.  The chairs in the sun are super uncomfortable! I had to move around every 10 minutes to make myself feel better.
author: Wilson T.

description: I got coffee today...an iced vanilla latte. So, so, so disappointing. You know when you look at the drink once it's made and you can already tell it's going to suck? Well, Sacred Grounds didn't disappoint. It was way WAY too sweet, it tasted like pure sugar. I couldn't drink it. I walked to Starbucks and threw it away on the way after taking a few small sips. I'm not that picky, but it wasn't good at all. Too bad, the place is cute. But I don't think I'll be returning.
author: Kray P.

description:
DO NOT GO HERE MY FRIENDS

I went here once I don't know why I guess to study...grab something to drink...getting out of my house but NEVER EVER AGAIN. This place is dark, smelly, moldy, and the trash of the neighborhood frequent the location. Never seen so much homeless people in my life in one area other then in a free meal line. 

Not only that I figured since I'm here I might as well stay here for the poetry reading or something like that...wrong, wrong, WRONG! So many crazies! I'm a nursing student at USF graduating this December so when I say crazy I mean clinically diagnostically crazy where we need to get out of there as soon as possible or the individual might get triggered and shoot up the place. 

If you fear for your lives DO NOT COME HERE.
author: Jenny N.

description: Dropped by here for a quick bite before the Alice concert. Good space. However, the lox bagel I got was kind of whatever's. My bagel tasted old and there was nothing special about it that I couldn't make.
author: Lisa T.

description: My coffee was absolutely terrible! It tasted old, cheap, and like cardboard. I got a white mocha with almond milk and it didn't even taste like a white mocha. It just tasted like plain coffee... a horrible one at that. Never getting coffee here again.
author: Hana K.

description: I really like this place. The sandwiches are soo good, and they come with chips, yeah! Fast service, chill atmosphere.
author: Steph L.

description:
I was feeling a bit exhausted today and thought maybe a nice hot cup of mocha would give me an energy boost, so I got my fix here at The Sacred Grounds Café.

When I walked in, it was fairly dim inside. The large windows provided just enough ambient light so you can navigate your way around.

The place was packed with loungers. Every one of them glued to their laptops. It was so quiet though I thought for a second that I must have teleported inside a library. I guess it's cool.

Anyhow, for a shade under three bucks I placed my order for a small cup of Mocha with half-n-half. It had just the right temperature and taste. Most important, it did the job! 

This place had free wifi connection. Besides their coffee selection, the menu offered breakfast items, lunch and a few entrees.

Pretty cool for a coffee shop I'd say...
author: Gary E.

description: This is the cutest cafe and the amazon Fog is amazing. Idk what they do to it but I can never recreate it at home. Delicious drinks and food at a reasonable price
author: Rory T.

description:
Whenever it's rainy and grey out, I find myself on autopilot headed to this inauspicious little place. It's quiet, clean, cozy, warm, there's tons of stuff to look at on the walls, and its got that quintessential chill neighborhood vibe going on. Low ceilings, brick walls, and plants lining the windows all make Sacred Grounds the perfect hole-in-the-wall to watch the world outside. The guy behind the counter, Teddy, is super-friendly and will recognize you after your first time here. And unlike most places in the neighborhood, you won't have to kill someone for an outlet.

True, the food is pretty basic, but San Francisco spoils me to the point at which sometimes all I want is a $4.50 make-your-own breakfast sandwich. Toast, eggs, avocado, pepper jack cheese. Plain Jane and proud. The London Fog is pretty damn good, too. 

Sacred Grounds is a home away from home. Haters gonna hate. I love this little coffee house.
author: Emma M.

description: So, I just ordered an Earl Grey tea here and asked the lady behind the counter if I could use her honey and she said, "No."  I offered to pay her 25 cents for it and she shook her head and said, "What do you want it for?"  Wow. Really?  The man behind her said something in Chinese to her and she begrudgingly have it to me. Has SF in the Haight really come to this??  The only reason I'm going 2 stars is because the ambience in here is nice and mellow.
author: anne r.

description: Great neighborhood spot. Excellent breakfast sandwiches, lattes, coffee and tea. Especially impressive to see the same husband and wife team everyday giving great service and knowing their regulars. Also has great sandwiches for lunch and is open late some days for open mic. Definitely my favorite spot in the neighborhood!
author: Katherine K.

description: If the food or coffee quality is just OK, their SF fog or Amazon fog teas are great, you have some nice pastries and, more important in my opinion, the place is quiet with a genuine SF vibe to it including the activities posters, open mic poetry and liberal posters.
author: Fabien-Pierre N.

description: The folks are rude, the bread stale. Even when i asked for water they brushed aside my comments. I had to ask them multiple times.
author: Ellen F.

description: This place is a health hazard. It was a cloudy day so we ordered the soup of the day (chicken and rice) to-go. The kitchen is completely open so we could see everything. The pot of soup is sitting out (NOT HOT), anyone that works in food service knows that soup either needs to be kept hot or refrigerated to be kept at a safe temperature. Before scooping out the soup she stuck her fingers into the soup to take a few things (??) off of the top and threw them on the floor. ugh RED FLAG. She then heated the soup in the microwave and handed it to us. We promptly placed it in the first trash can on the block. Not worth the risk.
author: Deja B.

description: The amazon fog is my favorite!  SF fog is pretty tasty too.  They taste the best when Teddy makes them.
author: Elizabeth G.

description:
This was a random drop-in for me. I was by the Saint Mary's Hospital, was hungry, and decided to go in here for a shot. What stuck to me the most from this place was the London Fog.

The interior is very cute. In a way, it reminds me of a hostile or a rustic lodge. My only issue was that the door was left wide open, and it was not a warm day in SF today... That aside, I really love how it is inside. They even have a corkboard where people put their advertisement up! 

Service was great! There were two workers, one male and one female. They were both very kind and patient when we seemed like we were taking forever to decide. There weren't a lot of people there, probably because it was early ... or because of other Yelp reviews ... Anyway, the food came out pretty fast. 

I ordered the Lox Bagel, which had cream cheese, smoked salmon, capers, onions, and tomatoes. I actually didn't know that they had tomatoes ... I usually avoid that. My boyfriend ordered the egg and toast with an extra order of bacon. I thought it seemed kind of cheap that they did not include bacon, and that $1.50 is the price of two bacon strips ... Well, I couldn't find anything else opened at that hour! 
The food was decent, not amazing, but not unbearable either. We also ordered two drinks: a white chocolate mocha and a London Fog. The London Fog was very impressive ... Usually, it tastes like Fruit Loops, and the Earl Grey is not so strong. Their Earl Grey is very strong, and I enjoyed that. I didn't try the White Mocha ... but I assumed it was good, seeing that my boyfriend drank it all. 

I might come back to this place again, perhaps for a sandwich if I am by the neighborhood.
author: Bianca W.

description:
Bad, BAD coffee - old and cold. 

Also, the restaurant owner got pissy at me when I was eating a fruit bar (from safeway) with my crappy coffee... 

From my few experiences here, it isn't a comfortable or friendly place to go.
author: Sarah H.

description:
I live very close to this shop and I go out of my way to avoid it.  I tried for a while to like it because it's so convenient for me, but EVERY SINGLE TIME that I went it was awful.  The food is gross, the coffee is bad.  I got a hot apple cider once, and it had an inch of disgusting tasteless goo in the bottom.  How do you screw that up?  It's just instant apple cider!
It's a dark hole that I avoid like the plague.
author: Rachel R.

description:
This place is all right. I'm not really into coffee but I believe that the drinks here do the trick. They have a varying availability of quiches, pies and cakes which can be fun. However, the rest of their menu is just ok, and a bit overpriced in my opinion. I actually try to avoid having to buy something to eat here, because it's just so, so average. The quality of food and drink probably also depends on who's working at the time--if it's the owner and/or his wife--a middle-aged white man and middle-aged Asian woman--you'll probably be ok. If you get a college girl helping you, however, be wary--in my experience, they don't really seem to know what's going on.

The environment here is airy, laidback and calm. My roommate really likes to study here because it's dead quiet, but I find the seats a little too hard. Even though chilling in cafes was never my thing in college, it's a close and decent getaway for USF students who need caffeine and are sick of the library. If you're in the mood for a snack, however, there are definitely better choices in the area.
author: Kate V.

description: Came here cause the Ben and Jerry's dude suggested it cause it was open mic... Best choice ever!! Thank you mister Ben and Jerry's dude working at the best place on earth ;)
author: Leah S.

description: Poor customer service and day old burned coffee.
author: Cub H.

description: Great place to study and do homework.  Food is over priced and they do not give out water, only tap.   Service is okay, they do not go out of their way to make the costumer feel welcomed but than again the main clients are college students on a budget.  Street parking only, but I like the decor and there are plenty of outlets for people typing up papers!
author: D R.

description:
Truly horrific.

Cold coffee. There's nobody there. Run down and not in a good way. Reading the old reviews, I could see how this place must have been something back in the day. But, it's clear that recent ownership doesn't have a clue. It wouldn't take much work--mostly just using one's brain--set things straight but I think it's doomed to failure due to past sins.
author: John S.

description:
Is it bad for me to like this place because I feel that it likes me?

Well, that's how sacred grounds feels. I spend long stretches of time here working some days and appreciate the cool dogs and sassy signs. (service bell encourages you to "ring for business or pleasure.")
author: Irene P.

description:
This place is wonderful and sooooo cozy. I've been coming here for two years now and I have never had a bad experience. Customer service is very friendly and they always ask how school is going, etc. I also think they are extremely patient considering the fact that they deal with a lot of demanding and snobby students all day, everyday. 

Breakfast sandwiches are delicious, and I highly recommend the Amazon Fog. Get your study on, smile, enjoy the warmth.
author: Olivia G.

description: Cool, quiet little coffee house with rustic vibes, decent diner-type food. Service could be better though.
author: Zach M.

description:
I haven't tried their coffee, so I don't have anything to say about that. I ordered the LOX bagel which is a bagel with cream cheese, salmon, tomatoes, onions, and capers. I asked for them to take out the onions and capers and replaced them with avocado. It was pretty delicious, but the size and shape of the bagel has differed every time I have ordered this.

I'm not a regular by any means, and I don't think I'd say that this was a place that you HAVE to try. Just your regular little coffee shop - nothing special.
author: Lisa D.

description:
I wanna tell people about this place. I wanna say Sacred Grounds is more comfortable than Emma's and it's less crowded than Coffee to the People or Cole Valley Cafe. And these things are true...

But, Sacred Grounds, you have so many, many problems.

1. I never get the coffee anymore. Why? Because it is always and without fail COLD! This is the only cafe I've ever gotten cold coffee.

2. It's winter. It's freezing. Why in God's name would you leave the doors wide open?!

3. Why would you ever choose soft rock for your default music station? Go out and pick up some jazz, classical, anything! I had to sit through "Total Eclipse of the Heart" and no one should ever, ever have to be exposed to this song again.

Please stop being retarded. I love you guys, really, but you need to make some changes if you wanna stay afloat.
author: Car C.

description:
Sacred Grounds is a stones throw away from my apt, so I visit often on my way to school. Generally, the coffee is fine, and the more specialized drinks are nothing special. Its awesome for convenience factor. 

The staff is pretty nice. I'm always a quarter short (large coffee and bagel w/ cream cheese = 4.95) and they won't charge your card unless your order is over $5 (no exceptions, it seems). The guy always lets it go, but i always pay him back on the next go around. 

The atmosphere is pretty chill - but there usually are flies buzzing around when the door is closed, which is annoying. 

Great for a cup of coffee on your way to school, wouldn't hang around too long though.
author: Sarah A.

description: This is a nice roomy coffee shop full of plants, and is a good place to go to get some reading done. The coffee is decent, though I had a overly sweet latte. Service was quite impersonal, and left me wondering if I had chosen the right place to stop by.
author: Jeremy B.

description:
A coffee house for me should be like a warm hug.  Somewhere that invites you in with open arms, and shouts "STAY A WHILE!"  On my way back from walking the dogs through the panhandle, and my caffeine headache was starting to kick in, we decided to hop in here for a cup o joe.  Students studying, no chatter, no comfy chairs, no love.  I didn't want to hug this coffee house, and I most definitely didn't want to stay a while.  

Good thing we had the pooches, and felt the need to leave asap.
author: Lauren F.

description: The most unique friendly FREE open mike night with amazing instrumentation, i.e. dijiridus, accordians, piano, a cappella, and other goodies, and an open-hearted wonderful hippified crowd. Mr. Natural (a latter day Jerry Garcia), the host, is a great guy -- the dream grandpa. This place tugs at the heartstrings in its authenticity. I didn't try the coffee so can't vouch for that. But, the spirit of the place makes the quality of the food a secondary concern.
author: Andrew K.

description: The food is decent, but as a local the staff is so welcoming and always prompt to assist. I would definitely support this local shop and take the opportunity to meet the owners!
author: Andres C.

description: Another of many quiet little coffee shops around USF.  This one is across the street from the SF Spiritual Enrichment Center, so we've eaten there twice.  The service was slow, but the food was good.  They have free wifi, but not too many people are actually using it.  There are a couple of internet workstations in the back, too.  Open mic night on Fridays, as is the custom in this area.
author: David D.

description:
Save a cup:  Bring your own mug and pay the price of a small coffee.

This is a block away from my apartment so it's very convenient for me. I have been hanging out here today for 2 hours using the WiFi and enjoying this big comfy lounge chair. The crowd has been steady and quiet. It's relaxing and cute in here. 

The food they're serving looks good- fresh fruit plate, bagel breakfast sandwiches, soup and salad, ooh they have beer, too.
author: Amy J.

description:
Sacred Grounds is one of the coffeehouses that make my neighborhood so cool, and this place is even on my street, though it's many blocks down.

I should probably warn you that I don't drink coffee.  Never have, never will.  I've tried it many times, but it is just gross to me.  So if you want to know about this (or any) place's coffee, please don't read my reviews.  In terms of yummy food and a cool atmosphere, Sacred Grounds has both of those.
author: John S.

description: Bagles are stale, hard. But the sandwiches are even worse. This coffee shop was bad and i thought it could not get worse, but when it changed hands, it showed how wrong I was... The best thing here are the chips that come with the sandwiches: i guess it's hard to screw up those... I am sitting there now and if I stop and focus on my sensations after their sandwich, I will barf over my phone.
author: alec m.

description:
The ambiance seemed kind of nice, and it's close to my work, so I tried to buy a pastry from here once.  I waited, and waited, and waited...but no one made any attempt to take my order.

Decided I should actually try one of their products before I cast judgment, I was finally able to buy an oat-cake thing--after, again, waiting a long time, even though the place was half-empty--service was very indifferent.  The oat-cake was pretty average.

Another panhandle cafe devoid of merit--seriously, how do these places stay in business?  Then again, this does seem to be the neighborhood of identically groomed women with big boots, wide glasses, and small dogs.  Hmm..
author: Nick H.

description:
I have to say, the only reason I go to this cafe at all is for the free wi fi, and because it's the closest caffeine fix from Zief Library. 

The ambiance is definitely lacking, as countless yelpers before me have pointed out. It feels too cavernous, too dimly lit.
author: Jen O.

description:
This is a neat place with a great vibe. There isn't anything quite like it in SF, or anywhere else for that matter. The sandwiches are good - nothing special, but I would eat here if you happen to stop by.

The open mic night is really special. It has been around since the 60s, and feels like something out of a bygone era. When I came here one time, an unassuming middle-aged woman borrowed my friend's guitar and began singing her lungs out about cannabis. Most of the performers aren't very good, but there are a few gems in the rough. Overall, worth the trip.
author: Dana L.

description: horrible place! awful. worst "coffee" ever. crappy service and not even in English any more.
author: Steve F.

description:
There's something very Santa Cruz about this place and I can't put my finger on it.
Maybe it's the 60-something ex-hippies that congregate here for poetry readings or the disproportionate 'Mystery Spot' architecture or the slightly-disheveled-chic of the place. 

Love the fact that you are raised up two-feet higher than the person taking your order.  I swear, everytime I'm at that counter, I feel like a God-among-men and it's already getting to my head.   After getting my coffee, I entertained the fantasy of yelling "THIS IS SPARTAAAA!!!!!!" and kicking the college kid square in the chest, but instead gave a modest 'thanks' and moved on to conquer other worlds.
author: Neej M.

description:
-1 star for really low ceilings. Even for me. And I'm not tall.
But other than that, I'm a new fan of Sacred Grounds. And to be honest, I've only had their bacon, egg and cheese breakfast sandwich on a croissant, but I've had it a few times and it definitely ranks in the top 5 in my never-ending quest for the best breakfast sando in SF.
author: Kate S.

description:
I love this place. I really do. It is close to my house, has free internet, the tea is fabulous (as in, some of the best I've ever had), the staff is the friendliest around, no one cares if you camp out and use the internet all day, and I love the cozy-feel-like-I'm-in-my-mom's-living room atmosphere.

My suggestions for gaining the much sought after 5 star rating-- stop microwaving the eggs for the breakfast sandwich, don't play talk radio (which only happens on rare occasion), and perhaps whenever possible try to speed up the food making process.

Caveat: I have never attended one of their poetry sessions/open mic nights but have walked by many a times while they were mid-event... my sarcastic attitude, coupled with my hatred for watching others embarrass themselves makes me think if I had been to such an event the Sacred Grounds star rating would plummet.
author: christi m.

description:
Kind of dumpy. Not a good place for vegetarians as the smell of meat cooking in that poorly ventilated space can be overpowering.

Communication can be an issue as the lady at the counter didn't seem to understand English very well. 

The latte would rank in the bottom 5 I have had in the city.

does have free wifi and plenty of place to sit.
author: Sushil N.

description: Fast. Friendly. Fabulous :)
author: Jennifer P.

description: Egg Croissant was delicious and iced coffee was pretty decent. Liked the decor- Will definitely stop by again soon!
author: Dana S.

description:
This is a neat little place. The food is good, not great. I didn't get a drink. 
I got the falafel with hummus, it was pretty good. They fill the bag with a bunch of broken up chips. Interesting.

There seems to be quite a lot of students here- a good place to chill, get some work done, read the paper.
author: Chili B.

description:
Forget the specific night poetry reading is, but do yo thang...everyone welcome and most of the ones doin it is da beat 60 years and older ones. Got some kinda toasted chicken salad sandwich and tea. 

Wow this is what Vesuvios must have been like when Ginsberg and Watts were spouting out poetry readings with shout outs from their peers.
author: miriam b.

description:
This is the coffee shop closest to my boyfriend's house, and I've visited at least fifteen or twenty times; though it probably goes without saying, given my one star review, there shall be no future visits! At first, I didn't mind Sacred Grounds: it's pretty quiet, there's free (if terribly spotty) Wi-Fi, and (as I said) it's close to my bf's house. But subsequent visits revealed 1) really inconsistent quality of the coffee; and 2) dishonesty on the part of the staff. 

To address point (1), I'll say that the coffee is average at best - nothing to write home about (esp. not in this city), but not terrible. Every so often, though, the coffee will just be shitty. I mean, really bad: weak, with bits of grounds in it. Yuck. Plus, the coffee is self-serve, which practice is a pet peeve of mine. 

Concerning point (2), let me relate the results of a longitudinal study I conducted over the course of three months. My favorite to-go breakfast from coffee/bagel shops is an everything bagel with light cream cheese. Notice that I did not say "regular cream cheese," but rather "light cream cheese." I'd been ordering this breakfast at Sacred Grounds for about a month when I got the hunch that the kitchen staff were just giving me regular cc, despite their acknowledgment of my order. The next few times I placed my order, I articulated the word "LIGHT" especially well (and always received a nod of agreement/acknowledgment/what have you from the clerk)...but the clerk never wrote "light" on the order slip. My experiment reached its conclusion when I finally witnessed a staff person smearing my bagel with regular cream cheese. Long (long) story short, the staff here are discourteous. It's like, if you don't have light cream cheese, just tell people that you don't have light cream cheese. Don't pretend that you do and slather on the regular stuff, capish? 

ALSO, the owner(?)/older staff member once mis-rang my bf's order - he charged us for the drinks he said he "forgot" to include in the total - and was really surly when we questioned his math skills. Yeah. Get a life! And start stocking light cream cheese like a normal establishment!
author: Kate G.

description:
In a word, comfy.

The food is mediocre, the service is indifferent, and the coffee is well... it's there.  While that doesn't sound like a sentence one would expect to find in a three star review, what this place has going for it is atmosphere.

It really feels like your hanging out in your friend's basement.  Most of the other patrons are your neighbors, you feel compelled to bus your own table, and there is really no pressure to leave three hours after you've finished your small coffee.

I certainly would not recommend this place to people who are looking for a good place to eat, but it's a great place for locals to come and relax and have a coffee on a Saturday morning or a beer on a Tuesday night.
author: Doug G.

description:
I discovered this place during a two-day training hosted by USF Libraries (Gleeson and Zief). A pleasantly larger selection of food than I exepcted upon walking into the coffee house, including salads, sandwiches, and some very wonderful home fries! Another great place in SF where you can find good coffee *and* alcohol (i.e., beers) under the same roof. My colleagues and I appreciated the friendly service. 

Definitely a nice place to chill--hope to have the opportunity to visit again at some point.
author: Ryan T.

description:
I really like the laid-back vibe of this coffeehouse. I mean, yes, it might be lacking in some of the upbeat cheeriness of other places, but sometimes I just want to roll out of bed, sip some coffee and surf the internet without feeling conspicuous. This would be new feeling for me since I just moved from LA where couture is required at all times.

I've also had some of their sandwiches (make sure you have at least 15 minutes to wait) and I thought they were very good. There is an extra-mayo thing going on which I really enjoy, but may not be for everyone. 

There's so many coffee places to choose from that I sort of like the quirky uniqueness of this place.
author: Katy W.

description:
Pros: 
- Cozy space, & perfect for studying.
- Free wireless.
- Absolutely killer Mihaly sandwich.

Cons: 
- Burnt coffee.
- Hot, stale air (that front door should always be propped open).
- Way too quiet for a coffee shop.

I could go either way. There are too many other good coffee spots in the greater Panhandle area for me to make any kind of special effort to come here in the future (unless I'm Jonesin' for a Mihaly sandwich, which is a possibility, I think).

Allegedly, they've got a great open mic night, though, so...your call.
author: Pete J.

description:
This may be the closest coffee shop to my apartment, but when I want a cup I walk on by to get it at the liquor store across the street. This place really is that bad.

Cold coffee, sour lattes, and pastries that look and taste like day or two old Safeway breads.

I really wish this place was better.
author: Laughlin E.

description: Very cool place with a garden shed/boho beach bungalo feel. Plenty of seating and comfy couches. It's a bit pricier than I would like. $1.95 for a cup of tea, but that seems to be the going rate for drinks nowadays and I would rather give my two bucks to a nice neighborhood cafe than to a giant chain place. Perfect for intimate get-togethers and catching up with old friends.
author: Teresa G.

description:
When I walked in, I should have noted the swarm of houseflies fluttering through the joint before deciding to go ahead and order that avocado sandwich anyway.  

What can you do, though?  You're hungry, and there ain't much in the nabe.  So you order up, and you blankly stare at your plate, appalled that you just paid $8.58 for a mess of overly mayonnaised stale bread with a side of generic corn chips.  (Though I will report that the avocado was fresh, as were the rest of the veggies on the sammy.  And the iced tea was decent.)
author: Ann M.

description:
Great place with friendly people.  Owner Bruce is such a sweetheart:) 

Highly recommend you visit there!
author: Alice L.

description:
This place has HISTORY - well it had a lot of history until the new owner threw most of it out. The food is mediocre and slow but what really made this place stand out for me is the Open Mics they have here. 

The open mics are more of a Hootenanny (yes, I did say that!). I've been here and folks get the crowd singing and stomping and having a great time with music. People travel from around the Bay to go to this open mic.  Also, the current MC is Mr. Natural is a cool kat as well - be sure to say hi! 

Go there for the music but the rest is up in the air.
author: Travis K.

description:
I practically lived here this past semester. It is a very homey place. It is really a neighborhood coffee shop. Great drinks await you inside. The owner is often there, very friendly guy. Expect to wait a while for your food to come, but when it does, it is always good. 

They also have wonderful open mic nights on Thursday, check it out. I have seen people from around the world/country perform here.
author: Simmy S.

description:
This is a difficult review to write. I like Sacred Grounds because there aren't many places in Inner Richmond/Panhandle that have such a unique feel. You step down into this place and it feels like you've walked into the middle of a story. Local newspapers and fliers are everywhere and the eclectic decor isn't just for show, it's been slowly accumulated over time and if you notice it for too long, the regulars will walk up to you and share the history behind it with you. 

The only problem with Sacred Grounds (a big one I'm afraid) is that the food is overpriced and sucks. I can't say anymore then that. I went in this morning for a latte, orange juice and two bagels. The latte was weak as water, the OJ was fine, but the bagels, I found out after I receive them, were left over from the day before. 

My suggestion is that if you decide to go to study or meet up with friends, smuggle food in with you.
author: Michael A.

description:
It's not always easy picking on the little guy, but for the small and quaint Sacred Grounds Café, located on the corner of Hayes and Cole on the Richmond's quiet side of Golden Gate's Panhandle park, service and quality are anything but sacred.  
 
How this corner eatery has been able to masquerade microwaved meals with what tastes like under the counter store-bought products is slightly befuddling, and tastes like a sin that takes away all pleasure leaving only guilt for wasting precious dollars. 
 
Sacred Grounds has every physical feature of a charming San Francisco family owned restaurant cafe. The walls and floors sport wood paneling, there are many quiet conversations taking place, and the crowd holds customers from ages 18 to 70. Considering its location next to USF, students gravitate towards the small cafe as a place to study during the day, making use of the free Wi-Fi offered on behalf of the cafe. 

 In a metaphorical sense though Sacred Grounds is much like a pinata that spits out one or two decently average pieces of candy, but nothing more. Breakfast, lunch and dinner are served all day which is convenient but that fact serves little apology to your wallet and stomach.

 The majority of the menu is the sandwich list which offers single cold cuts starting around $6, burgers for $7, and the delicacy sandwiches(salmon or a rib eye steak) are $10. The list is lengthy but its length is its only ambition. 
 
A half and half combination of soup and sandwich($ 6.95) is the most economical lunch option. Limited to only turkey, ham, roast beef, pastrami, and a cheese toastie for the half the sandwich feels cheap and unsatisfying considering the quality of those choices. The turkey boasts less flavor than processed turkey found in an Oscar Meyer Lunchables pack, and the vegetables and condiments are not fresh enough to make that fact forgettable. The sourdough bread is over toasted , and thoughts like "Why didn't I make a lunch?" surface quickly. The half and half combination comes with a side of tortilla chips, if you want the home fries, which in actuality are microwaved cold roasted potatoes, enjoy having to fork over an additional $3.25, they do not come included.
 
When it comes to soup (cup $3.75/bowl $4.75) choose carefully between the two daily offerings. Sacred Ground's vegetarian chili is savory and a good option for a cold day, but the clam chowder does no justification to the argument for West Coast chowder. It was thin, watery, and unfulfilling, after a couple of bites a companion dropped his spoon sadly giving up. 
 
The three dinner entrees share similar problems with the lunch options. The salmon dinner($12) which is served with a side of caesar salad and home fries gives you exactly what you pay for. The salmon took over 20 minutes and upon delivery it was lukewarm . The outside felt rubbery and overcooked, and the inside was suspiciously pink, watery, and dull.  

 The dessert menu is small, but had some saving value. The carrot cake($3.75) is throughly layered with a thick vanilla cream cheese frosting that compliments the moist, smooth cake and excites taste buds.
 
Sacred Grounds does not fail as a coffee lounge, but it fails as an institution that promises a worth while meal. There is no wait staff, and do not be surprised if whoever is taking your order needs to come from behind the register to answer a question about their own menu. If you're in a rush try and avoid ordering anything you couldn't make at home, because the wait is long and unworthy of your time for the end result. In the end Sacred Grounds strives in atmosphere, but regrettably falls short of the  culinary cut.
author: Chris C.

description:
Great coffee house right around the corner from my place. They always have good hot food, and it seems to act as a de-facto meeting place for the neighborhood. Haven't had a chance to catch the weekly open mike yet, but it looks like a good time.


-free wifi.
author: Craw H.

description:
Love Sacred Grounds!  If you live in the neighborhood or go to USF I think it's the perfect place for grabbing coffee or reading for awhile.  They're always nice, too. 

(Quick story, though: I did see a lady try to give back a smoothie because it was the wrong kind, and the girl behind the counter looked so SUPER annoyed I wanted to just say, "I'll take it!".  Maybe the lady mumbled or changed her mind...)
author: Mark S.

description:
i came here for the open mic night a few weeks ago and was absolutely delighted by the place.  despite living across the park, i'm pretty unfamiliar with the richmond and had no idea sacred grounds even existed!

the entire set-up reminded me of some east coast university professor's finished basement (mind you, that's a good thing by me since i grew up back east and have major basement nostalgia).  the ceiling was low, the tables and chairs didn't match, there were all sorts of books scattered around, and the art was more homey than eclectic.  the crowd (only ~20 ppl) was remarkably diverse--from old couples, probably in their late 60s, to younger folk in their early 20s.  the entire vibe of the spot was just really comfortable, friendly, and laid back.  most of the music was pretty folksy (which i love) and while the performers varied in experience, all were incredibly talented.

the part where they serve the food/drinks is way in the back and they provide a small selection of beers and wines too.  one problem with the set up is that you have to walk right in front of the performers and straight in the middle of the audience to get from the door or tables to the serving area (or the bathrooms), and that's a little awkward in such a small space.  they're also a little tight on space/seating, but people seemed really friendly and willing to just crash on the floor or sit with each other at the tables.

sacred grounds is simply charming, and if you're into listening to some good music with no pretentions or fluff, then this is your spot...and you may even catch the occasional yelper in performance!
author: Roshni R.

description: My co-worker went there for a latte.  She got a latte...with a dime in the bottom.  I got something once they called a "bagel" but was really just fluffy paste with dairy product on top.  If you're in the neighborhood and you need caffeine, it is completely worthwhile to walk the extra couple blocks to another joint.  Just don't go here.
author: Polly Enmity P.

description: Now I can't really comment about how the coffee used to be or the energy since I've only recently discovered this place.  However from what I've seen, the new owner Bruce is doing an excellent job getting the place going again.  There are new computers for Internet access along with free WiFi for laptop users.  The schedule for Poetry Readings(Wednesdays), Open Mic(Thursdays), and Music(Fridays/Saturdays) is packed pretty solid through August.  Also their vegetarian chili is awesome as well as the Mihaly Sub.  Go check it out.  www.sacredgroundscafe.com
author: Derek D.

description: Food was horrible. Ordered the Falafel sandwhich and there were two falafels in it... on top the falafels were stale they tasted hard and dry on the outside.  Ordered the house fries and those sucked as well. Some were cooked alright but most were still uncooked in the middle.  Avoid this place.
author: D n.

description: If you want a "true San Francisco experience," this is your place.  The Thursday night open mike night was awesome.  I love the hippy 60s vibe and the crowd in general was very supportive of the musicians.  I can't comment on the food because I didn't eat here, but there isn't really much need to eat.  The music is enough food.
author: Joanna S.

description: Excellently located for USF, and a piece of history to boot. If you know what I'm talking about, let's rap.
author: Megan W.

description: I gotta admit, even though their espresso machine ain't the best, surprisingly their iced latte's pretty good. Its not too bitter and not burnt either. Prices are moderately priced but i wish they have frequent coffee drinker cards for regular's like me hehe :)
author: Zoey Z.

description:
I have been here twice and definitely won't make it three.  Let's put it this way: I was inspired to join Yelp just to warn people about this place.  Set the scene: Saturday morning, I'm new to the neighborhood and psyched to check out the local coffeeshop.  I ordered the tuna melt and a coffee, both of which were completely mediocre, so the lack of ambiance and consideration on the staff's part slightly soured the experience.........but whatever.  Maybe they were having a bad day.  So I decide to give it another shot the next weekend.  My friends and I order one latte and three bagels to go: one with cream cheese, one with cream cheese and veggies, and one with cream cheese, veggies, avocado, and turkey.  The tab comes out to be $23 and change, after the owner spent about half an hour ringing up all of the add-ons separately.  That seemed a bit steep (even for SF) so I asked him to double-check the bill, to which he snapped, "It's $23.  Do you want to watch me while I ring it up a second time?"  To which I said yes, although a bit embarrassing but $23 for 3 bagels and a latte?!?  Come on.  This time, after another agonizing process of $1.30 avocado charge here, $.50 tomato/$.50 onion/$.50 cucumber charge there etc, it comes out to $16 and change.  He gave us an extra $5 bill to try to make up for his previous rudeness when we requested that he double-check the bill.  

...........................so, fast forward 15 minutes.  We're still waiting for our food, even though it's not busy at all.  When we ask him about the status, he replies with a REALLY sour attitude that they're working on it and that us standing around watching them isn't going to help the situation.  (even though that is not what we had been doing)  Unfortunately, this comment set my Latina girlfriend through the roof and it became quite heated in there for a minute.  She stormed out.  Finally, when the food was ready after about another 5 minutes, they hand me the bag.............but there's no latte.  "I also had a latte," I say.  "Oh, OK, what size?" asks the girl behind the counter, as if this was the first she had heard of it.  Even this was a bit much for me.  I left.  But not without making them give me back the $2 for the latte.  

Obviously my second experience there was extremely uncomfortable, shattering the otherwise complete silence that was present in the dining area.  I don't like drama and try to steer clear of places that inspire me to create some.  It's sad but true that the closest place to my house sucks.  Oh well, it just gives me another excuse to go out and explore the neighborhood.

ps - I know this was such a rant, but I obviously needed to vent, so thanks for reading.
author: Kate B.

description:
it was completely empty, the food was stale (and looked like it had been sitting out with all the many flies for too long...)

they also had the worst and by far the blandest Thai iced tea i've ever tasted..
author: M M.

description: I've been here mostly to hear my friend play guitar, evenings that have always been really fun and relaxing. The open mics have been great too. The place reminds me of one of my boyfriend's houses actually, with the pictures and posters they have. (A good association.) The food, yes, is maybe what you'd expect based on first impressions of the place- not spectacular, just okay. Which is fine for me, but I didn't have high expectations to begin with. And you can't mess up grilled cheese too much.
author: Barbs J.

description: This place is dungeonous.  Sometimes that's not a good thing, but on an already cold, dreary day the combination of being underground, drinking coffee, and reading a book or poking around online can feel just right.
author: Katie S.

description:
i really want to like this place. i really do. i come here all the time to study because they have free wireless...
but the coffee is always cold and the food is not that great...
HOWEVER, the friendly people who work there more than make up for any shortcomings.
author: eve l.

description: Food is good. Open mic night is great. Prices are good. Nice place to relax.
author: Tom A.

description:
Meh...that about sums up this place.  It's just one of those joints you go to for convenience and 'cause you can't decide on what to have.

It's a really chill cafe.  Yeah, it ain't all fancy schmancy, but I appreciate the coziness of the place.  I like the fact that they have some board games and a shelf full of odd books.

The service isn't all that great, but that's fine, 'cause I don't need to tip them much.  If they'd perk up a little, I'd be a lot more inclined to give em a lil sumn sumn.  

I've had a few decent hot sandwiches here.  Given the simple ingredients and quality of those sammies, I know I can find a place with more savory stuff at the same price, but hey, I'm lazy what can I say.  The only thing I think I'd ever get excited for is their veggie lasagna, ravioli, or quiche w/soup, but that's only if I'm craving it.

I'll be back for more, but it might be begrudgingly.
author: Dwigt K. S.

description: I "gently" expressed how intimidatingly quiet it is inside.  I felt obligated to turn my phone on vibrate upon noticing that none of the patrons this afternoon were chattering at all.  The atmosphere inside is Starbucks' exact opposite, quite calm.  The cappuccino was typical, but dropping in this afternoon was not about the drink:  free WiFi.  I now know where to hang out and wait the next time misis & I are in the area for our routine dental appointment.  Hers will be up again in four months. =)
author: Erick ..

description:
you know how most cafes/coffee shops claim they have free wi-fi?  well, they lie.  lying lying bastards.  

i love you for your wi-fi, sacred grounds.  your chai is delicious, you are never so packed i can't find a seat, and you have an old school bicycle hanging from the wall.  that's worth a ten minute walk past all the other lying bastard coffee shops to reach you.

see you tomorrow.
besos,
shoshi
author: Shoshaunna P.

description: Cozy and inviting - an earthy place. Free wireless and numerous electrical outlets. Lots of students from USF, plus some hospital trade.
author: dave c.

description: Sacred Grounds won some stars back for their outstanding Sudanese chicken sandwich. Listed as spicy, but not really, it's bursting with flavor and  done up splendidly on a French roll. Absolutely delicious.
author: Jason B.

description: i am probably being a bit generous with my review here. i thought the ambiance of this place was really cool and it had a cozy feeling inside which is why i am giving it a 4 and not a 3. the tuna melt i had here was interesting because it had hummus on it. it was good, but for some reason later in the deal it left a strange taste in my mouth. my friend (a local) had the vegetarian chile which she loves. to me it was way too watery and soupish to be chile but hey, she likes it. i am typically someone who really cant eat lunch or dinner at a coffee house because the food isn't usually restaurant quality. for a muffin though or cookie, yeah i would go here.
author: Yelper Y.

description: OK atmosphere and location, but service is super slow and food is terrible.  A short list of problems for the once every 3 month visits I keep giving the place: stale chips, gamey (possibly rancid) chicken, never get my bagel right, coffee is...unremarkable, internet never seems to work...I really wish this place was better, but I am always disappointed when I leave.
author: Robb K.

description: Went here for my morning coffee, instead of my usual Starbucks non-fat latte with whipped cream.  Got a medium non-fat latte, which tasted not good and definitely not better than the Starbucks, and payed 3,something dollars for it, making it more expensive than Starbucks for less coffee.  Needless to say, I will not return.
author: Marijke D.

description: open mic nights are always fun, and combined with veggie chili, it's just funner! but seriously, this is a great local joint, and they make a mean hot chocolate with chocolate whipped cream. just melts my heart away.
author: Bee H.

description: the service is bad; i ordered a belgian waffle and it came several minutes after my mocha (which was not that good). the menu board said it comes w/ fruit and whipped cream, but this came plain, and when i asked about the fruit and noted the menu board, the counterperson said "it could but i didn't charge you for it." it was already almost 11 bucks just for the mocha and waffle. lame. staff seems uninterested, the atmosphere is alright for a gloomy day like this but if you don't want to bother w/ poor service and mediocre food, then i would try to avoid this place.
author: Robin L.

description: I live right across from this cafe and I have to say that the food and service have improved tremendously since the new owners took over recently.  The sandwiches are fresh, and the service is faster and friendlier.  Huge improvement.
author: A L.

description:
i stumbled upon/into this place with two friends after a walk through the park.  we just wanted a place to sit and chat before having dinner down the street.  it was dead silent with some studious-looking folks reading and working on laptops.  at first i thought audible conversation wouldn't be welcome.  then, the girl behind the counter seemed to anticipate the need for background noise, and put on some tunes; thus all was good.

i couldn't stop marveling at the adorable/eccentric decor.  one of my friends said it was a little too cliche, but i thought it seemed lovingly random -- which maybe means it was cliche indeed.  anyway, we each had a yummy beverage, and i'm curious about the food.  it was the perfect place to relax as twilight set in, and a lovely complement to this understated stretch of hayes.  i'd love to come back alone with a book.
author: Philip M.

description: I have mixed feelings on this place. It is a great place to go if you want peace and quiet to read, study, or browse the internet. If you want to chat with someone it almost seems like you are making too much noise because it is eerily quiet here. I was looking for a specific place to eat breakfast, but happened to stumble across this place and decided to stop because I couldn't find the place I was originally looking for. I had the breakfast sandwich and it was pretty good and I had a caramel machiatto and it was blazing hot! I burnt my tongue horribly, so beware. The service was terrible. We walked in and the girl at the register just stared at us. She didn't say hello, how are you, can I help you, nothing! I personally thought it was rude, but whatever. I will most likely never go back because it is not near where I live at all and it just wasn't really my kind of place. If I lived in the neighborhood, I might think about it.
author: Carly W.

description: i needed food, wi-fi and a place near usf. i got all three. this quiet cafe is nice. the chili was ok. i didn't get a drink, but i got some work done and was satiated.
author: Anita C.

description: The coffee used to deserve a 5/5 - but sadly no more.  The decor leads us to call this 'the hippy cafe'.  The change of ownership has affected the energy here very much for the worse, and now I can't go in.  I sincerely hope they figure it out and it returns to its former glory because it would be sad to see yet another community space lose its glow.
author: robin b.

description: This is one of the best coffee shops in San Francisco. They have a very friendly staff and the best Mocha I have ever had. It is a good place to go and do homework, read a book, or just hang out with friends. They always play good music. Anyone that doesn't like it there has no idea what they are talking about.
author: Brock L.

description: I became a regular here after becoming a patient at St. Mary's and then at the clinic. This cafe is a pleasant discovery and I really like waiting here between appointments or while my prescription is being filled. Generally, it's pretty quiet and I like that people usually keep to themselves. It doesn't have the transient feel of a chain like Starbucks, which I like but these days is less a coffee shop and more of a stopover for people with busier destinations. At Sacred Grounds, folks still like to order their coffee and sit down with the paper, study, or conduct a low key conversation. It's a nice change of pace when it is busy, though, because a little place like this deserves the business. The staff is often super-friendly and they treat every customer with a very affable, personal approach. On one of my first visits, the background music consisted of Diana Krall, and I subsequently got into a fond chat about her with the gentleman behind the counter. The food is fantastic, something I would have never expected from a coffee house. I know that a lot of cafes these days are branching out into serving meals that are more than just sandwiches and pastries, but I've enjoyed many delicious breakfasts here. While the service might seem slow, it's only because the staff seems to be a homegrown bunch that strives to personally cater to each patron. You walk in here, not for instant gratification, but to be at home.
author: Joseph R.
